title: Riemann Hypothesis Research Curriculum
description: Comprehensive foundation for GPIA's exploration of the Riemann Hypothesis, from complex analysis basics to quantum mechanical interpretations

lessons.title: Analytic Functions and Continuation
key_theorems: Cauchy-Riemann equations define analyticity
Analytic continuation is unique
Laurent series represent functions with poles
lessons.critical_insight: The Riemann zeta function's definition changes depending on domain - analytic continuation allows us to extend beyond Re(s) > 1 to all of C except s=1
lessons.exercise: Prove that analytic continuation of sum(n^(-s)) from Re(s)>1 gives unique function on C\{1}

lessons.title: Residues and Poles
key_theorems: Residue theorem: contour integral = 2πi * sum of residues
Argument principle relates winding number to poles and zeros
Residue at simple pole: Res(f,a) = lim_{z->a} (z-a)f(z)
lessons.critical_insight: The zeta function has exactly one simple pole at s=1 with residue 1. This is detectable via contour integration
lessons.exercise: Compute residue of ζ(s) at s=1 and verify it equals 1
verification_criteria: Uses limit definition or Laurent series

lessons.title: Functional Equations in Complex Analysis
key_theorems: Functional equations relate function values at different points
For ζ(s): relates ζ(s) to ζ(1-s) via gamma functions and trigonometric functions
Functional equation preserves zeros under specific transformations
lessons.critical_insight: The functional equation ζ(s) = 2^s π^(s-1) sin(πs/2) Γ(1-s) ζ(1-s) is KEY to understanding why zeros come in conjugate pairs and why Re(s)=1/2 is special
lessons.exercise: Verify the functional equation for ζ(s) at s=2 using the explicit definition

modules.title: Riemann Zeta Function: Definition and Properties

lessons.title: Dirichlet Series and Zeta Definition
key_theorems: ζ(s) = sum_{n=1}^∞ n^(-s) converges for Re(s) > 1
Analytic continuation extends to Re(s) > 0 except s=1
Abscissa of convergence σ_c = 1 for zeta function
lessons.critical_insight: The Dirichlet series definition only works in half-plane. Critical line Re(s)=1/2 is where zeta is most interesting and least understood
lessons.exercise: Prove that sum_{n=1}^∞ n^(-s) diverges for Re(s) <= 1 (on critical line, behavior unknown!)
verification_criteria: Uses comparison tests or Dirichlet convergence

lessons.title: Euler Product Formula
key_theorems: ζ(s) = prod_p (1 - p^(-s))^(-1) for Re(s) > 1
Establishes connection between zeta zeros and prime distribution
Product converges absolutely in half-plane Re(s) > 1
lessons.critical_insight: Euler product is fundamental: zeta function ENCODES ALL INFORMATION about prime distribution. Zeros of ζ(s) directly control prime density
lessons.exercise: Derive Euler product from Dirichlet series definition for ζ(s)

lessons.title: Trivial and Non-Trivial Zeros
key_theorems: Trivial zeros: s = -2, -4, -6, ... (from gamma function poles)
Non-trivial zeros: all conjectured on critical line Re(s) = 1/2
Critical strip: 0 < Re(s) < 1 contains all non-trivial zeros
lessons.critical_insight: RH states: ALL non-trivial zeros satisfy Re(s) = 1/2. Not just 'most' or 'on average' - ALL with probability 1 (if true)
lessons.exercise: Locate 3 trivial zeros using functional equation and explain why they don't matter for RH

modules.title: From Zeta Function to Prime Distribution

lessons.title: The Explicit Formula
key_theorems: psi(x) = x - sum_ρ x^ρ/ρ - (1/2)log(2π) where ρ are zeros
Riemann's explicit formula relates prime counting to zero locations
RH implies improved bounds on prime density
lessons.critical_insight: This formula shows explicitly HOW zero locations affect primes: each zero ρ creates oscillation term x^ρ/ρ. If all ρ have Re(ρ)=1/2, error term is minimized
lessons.exercise: Explain how zero at ρ=1/2+14.134725i affects distribution of primes around x=10^6

lessons.title: Prime Number Theorem and Zeta Connection
key_theorems: π(x) ~ x/ln(x) as x -> ∞ (Prime Number Theorem)
Equivalent to: ζ(s) ≠ 0 for Re(s) >= 1
RH implies: π(x) - li(x) = O(x^(1/2) log x)
lessons.critical_insight: No zero on line Re(s)=1 is already proven (PNT). But zeros at Re(s)<1/2 would make primes more irregular. Zeros AT 1/2 give smoothest behavior
lessons.exercise: Show how zero-free region Re(s) > 1 - C/log|t| leads to prime density bounds
verification_criteria: Relates zero location to error bounds

lessons.title: Berry-Keating Hamiltonian Conjecture
key_theorems: Berry-Keating propose Hamiltonian H such that eigenvalues are 1/2 + iρ where ρ are zeta zeros
Physical interpretation: zeta zeros as quantum energy spectrum
Berry conjecture: such Hamiltonian exists and is explicitly constructible
lessons.critical_insight: If true, RH becomes a statement about physics: the mysterious spectral operator must have ALL eigenvalues on critical line. This gives RH a PHYSICAL reality
lessons.exercise: Propose form of Hamiltonian operator that might have zeta zero spectrum

lessons.title: Random Matrix Theory and GUE Correspondence
key_theorems: Zeros of ζ(s) show pair correlation matching GUE (Gaussian Unitary Ensemble) random matrices
Level repulsion: zeros spacing statistical distribution matches random matrix predictions
Montgomery-Odlyzko law: two-point correlation function agrees with GUE
lessons.critical_insight: Zeta zeros DON'T behave like random points - they show level repulsion like eigenvalues of random matrices. This regularity suggests underlying structure
lessons.exercise: Compare spacing distribution of first 100 zeta zeros to Poisson and GUE predictions

lessons.title: Quantum Chaos and Trace Formula
key_theorems: Gutzwiller trace formula connects periodic orbits to quantum spectrum
Zeta zeros might arise from periodic orbits in some chaotic system
Berry-Keating uses semiclassical quantization of classical system
lessons.critical_insight: Quantum chaos perspective: if zeta zeros are eigenvalues of a quantum system, there's a classical system generating them. Understanding that classical system might prove RH
lessons.exercise: Outline how trace formula could connect prime distribution (classical) to zeta zeros (quantum)

lessons.title: Riemann-Siegel Formula and Computational Methods
key_theorems: Riemann-Siegel formula: efficient computation of ζ(1/2+it) with error terms
Z(t) = e^(iθ(t)) ζ(1/2+it) real on critical line
O(t^(1/4)) complexity for computation at height t
lessons.critical_insight: This formula is WHY we can verify 10^13 zeros computationally. Without it, would need arbitrary precision arithmetic on full ζ(s)
lessons.exercise: Implement Riemann-Siegel for t=14.134725 (first zero) and verify |ζ(1/2+it)| is small

lessons.title: Zero Finding and Verification Algorithms
key_theorems: Argument principle: count zeros via contour integral of log derivative
Bracket zeros using sign changes of Z(t) function
Verify zeros to arbitrary precision using Newton's method
lessons.critical_insight: Finding 10^13 zeros requires automation. Argument principle scales; Newton refinement achieves arbitrary precision
lessons.exercise: Use argument principle to count zeros in rectangle 0 < Re(s) < 1, 0 < Im(s) < 100

lessons.title: Statistical Analysis of Zero Distribution
key_theorems: Average zero spacing ~ 2π/log(height)
Normalized spacings follow Wigner semicircle law (GUE prediction)
Higher moments match RMT predictions
lessons.critical_insight: Statistics CONFIRM RH for first 10^13 zeros. Deviations would appear in higher moments first. This guides computational search
lessons.exercise: Analyze spacing of 20 known zeros - compute mean, variance, max/min ratio

lessons.title: Zero-Free Regions and Conditional Results
key_theorems: Known zero-free region: Re(s) > 1 - C/log|t| for critical strip
Vinogradov-Korobov: C can be taken as c(log|t|)^(-3/5) (log log|t|)^(-1/5)
RH implies C can be taken arbitrarily large
lessons.critical_insight: Current best unconditional result still assumes no zeros VERY close to Re(s)=1. RH would eliminate this assumption entirely
lessons.exercise: Sketch zero-free region graphically and explain why it's not contradiction to RH

lessons.title: Generalized Riemann Hypothesis and L-functions
key_theorems: Generalized RH (GRH): all zeros of L(s,χ) lie on Re(s)=1/2
Applies to Dirichlet L-functions, Artin L-functions, etc.
GRH implies stronger results on prime distribution in arithmetic progressions
lessons.critical_insight: RH is a special case of pattern holding across ENTIRE family of L-functions. Understanding GRH might illuminate RH
lessons.exercise: Formulate GRH for Dirichlet character χ and discuss verification strategy

assessment_criteria.conceptual_understanding: Can explain why zero location matters to prime distribution
assessment_criteria.technical_mastery: Can implement computational verification and statistical analysis
assessment_criteria.research_readiness: Can identify open problems and propose novel approaches
assessment_criteria.mathematical_rigor: Uses precise definitions and acknowledges limitations of evidence

next_milestones: Attempt novel proof approach (based on learned insights)
